intro.description: Now, we're going to work on a more complex problem - asking ASSET to generate multiple instances of our Fishing vessel. We do this by including instructions in the control file regarding which elements of the scenario to change, and how to change them.

item.title: View the scenario
item.description: Start off by re-opening the scenario file we've been working with - the one that contains a single fishing vessel.

item.title: Decide what to change
item.description:
Right, the scenario's open. What shall we change? I know, let's get ASSET to create 10 fishing vessels, all with different start locations, and with different speeds that they conduct the Wander behaviour.
There's a convenience function for changing the initial location, but we will need to sort out how to specify the Wander speed. Have a look at how to specify the path to the Wander element. It's the Value attribute of the Speed element, contained within the Wander element.

item.title: Create duplicate control file
item.description: Now, we don't want to overwrite our existing control file, so copy/paste our existing trial1.xml using either the keyboard or the menus. Name the new control file trial_multi.xml.

item.title: Open the scenario controller
item.description: Next, double-click on our new control file to open it in the xml editor. Next, open the ScenarioController element and give it a ScenarioGeneator child element. It's this element that handles generation of both multiple participants and multiple scenarios.

item.title: Add participant generation code
item.description:
Next, add a MultiParticipantGenerator element to the ScenarioGenerator.
Next, add a ParticipantVariance element to this. A ParticipantVariance describes the variances to apply to a single participant - specified using the participant name.

item.title: Add specification for multi participant generation
item.description: So, set the name attribute of the ParticipantVariance to Fisher One, and set the number to 10 - to say we want 10 of them. Next, we'll set the initial locations, so add a ParticipantLocation element to this. Give this an area of 50 to 51 degs North, and -8 to -9 degs West.

item.title: Add the Wander speed variance
item.description: Next we're going to specify how to vary the Wander speed. Start by adding a Variance element to the ParticipantVariance for Fisher One. Next, right-click on the LocationArea element and select Replace with an Attribute element. Name this element as 'Vary the wander speed'. Next. specify that we're going to vary the attribute through a Range of values from 2 to 10, and use the name Value. We also need to tell the Variance element what it's going to apply to, so put /Wander/Speed in the id field. This phrase is an follows the XPath regular expression standard - but essentially it just matches XML Element names, with single slashes showing the parent/child relationship, and double-slashes matching against any number of parent/child tiers.

item.title: Load the new controller file
item.description: Now, save our new control file, and drag it from the Navigator to the Scenario Controller view. As you drop it, you should see the current tab switch to Multiple Scenarios. item.title: Inspect the generated scenario
item.description: Before we run the scenario, let's have a look at what ASSET has generated. In the Navigator window, have a look in the Results folder. You'll see a copy of the control file, and a folder called 1. ASSET numbers the generated scenarios, so you can see it's just created the one. Open this folder and you'll see a single file titled Cheat sheet scenario.xml. Double-click to open it. Inside this scenario you'll see that there are now 10 surface participants, each with a unique vessel name. Have a look at the Wander behaviours, and you'll see that there are a range of speeds specified. Note, the random numbers have lots of decimal places, the format attribute of the Variance element we used allows us to specify the number of decimal places used.
